meta.title: Idiopathic inflammatory myopathies: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis

content:
Introduction

Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by progressive, symmetric, proximal muscle weakness.  It is usually painless, although mild myalgia and muscle tenderness may occur.  Dermatomyositis is a similar disorder but is associated with certain typical skin findings.  Both conditions may occur independently or as a paraneoplastic manifestation of malignancy.



Recently, polymyositis as a distinct clinical entity has been questioned.  As diagnostic testing and classification schemes have been refined, many cases that were previously categorized as polymyositis can now be better classified as one of a group of immune-mediated myopathies (IMMs).  In addition to polymyositis and dermatomyositis, major IMM categories include inclusion body myositis, immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy, antisynthetase syndrome, and overlap myopathy (ie, myositis occurring in the context of another recognized autoimmune connective tissue disorder).

Pathophysiology



Dermatomyositis and polymyositis (as well as the other IMMs) are believed to arise from a combined humoral and cell-mediated autoimmune response directed against skeletal muscle tissue, leading to inflammation, muscle fiber damage, and microangiopathy with muscle ischemia.  In dermatomyositis, this immune response likely involves the upregulation of type 1 interferon and also targets cutaneous structures.



A unifying pathogenic mechanism has been elusive, but several factors are thought to contribute to disease development:



  • Genetic predisposition:  Certain genes associated with the immune system may increase susceptibility.  For example, certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) serotypes (eg, HLA-A*68) are associated with an increased risk for dermatomyositis.
  • Environmental triggers:  Viral infections (eg, HIV, hepatitis C virus, coxsackievirus), medications (eg, statins, penicillins, sulfonamides), and ultraviolet light exposure have been reported to trigger dermatomyositis and other IMMs.
  • Autoantibodies:  Antibodies targeting specific proteins in muscle and skin cells are often present, but pathogenic effects are uncertain.

Risk factors



  • Family history:  Having a close relative with an autoimmune disease may increase the risk.
  • Autoimmune diseases:  The risk for IMM syndromes is increased in patients with other preexisting autoimmune disorders.  In addition, overlap myopathy can be seen with other autoimmune connective tissue diseases (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis).
  • Age:  Polymyositis is most common at age >20.  Dermatomyositis has increased the incidence in late childhood and adolescence (ie, juvenile dermatomyositis) and again at age 45-60.  Inclusion body myositis occurs predominantly at age >50.

Clinical presentation

Dermatomyositis



  • Muscle weakness:  Muscle weakness typically affects the proximal muscles in the shoulders, hips, and thighs, leading to difficulty with climbing stairs, rising from a seated position, and lifting objects.  In advanced cases, muscle atrophy and distal limb involvement may occur.
  • Skin rash:  Pathognomic skin lesions include the following:
    • Heliotrope rash (
      image 1
      ):  violaceous discoloration on the eyelids
    • Gottron papules (
      image 2
      ):  reddish-purple bumps over the small joints of the hands
    • Other photosensitive dermatoses:  erythematous macules and plaques over the neck, shoulders, and upper back (shawl sign)


Skin lesions in dermatomyositis are frequently associated with burning discomfort and pruritus, which can be severe.  Skin and muscle symptoms may not be concurrent, and patients may develop only skin lesions with no noticeable muscle weakness (clinically amyopathic dermatomyositis).

Polymyositis



  • Muscle weakness:  similar to dermatomyositis, but without the characteristic skin rash.


Both conditions may also present with:



  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) from oropharyngeal or esophageal involvement
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD)
  • Cardiomyopathy

Other IMMs



  • Inclusion body myositis (IBM) differs from other IMMs in having a more insidious and protracted course.  Distal limb muscle involvement (eg, forearm muscles, intrinsic hand muscles) occurs much more commonly, and symptoms may be asymmetric.
  • Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM) typically manifests with severe proximal limb weakness and dysphagia.  Creatine kinase (CK) levels are often dramatically elevated, and antibodies against hydroxymethylglutaryl–coenzyme A reductase are often present.
  • Antisynthetase syndrome is an IMM syndrome characteristically associated with autoantibodies against aminoacyl–transfer RNA (tRNA) synthetases (eg, anti-Jo-1).  It often has a relatively abrupt onset and classically presents with a triad of myositis, arthritis, and ILD, although only a minority of patients have all 3 features at the time of diagnosis.  This condition also is associated with Raynaud phenomenon and mechanics' hands, a distinctive finding of fissured, hyperkeratotic plaques on the fingers and palms.  Regardless of classification, a positive test for anti-Jo-1 is associated with an increased risk for ILD.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of the IMMs usually relies on a combination of clinical features, laboratory tests, imaging studies, and muscle biopsy.  Muscle biopsy may not be needed in patients with proximal muscle weakness and the pathognomonic skin lesions of dermatomyositis but is required for evaluation in other cases.

Laboratory tests



  • CK and other muscle enzymes (eg, aldolase, aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase) are elevated in almost all patients with active IMM syndromes.  CK levels correlate with disease activity and response to treatment.
  • Inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein) are elevated in most cases but are often normal in patients with inclusion body myositis.
  • Complete blood count is typically normal, but normocytic anemia (ie, anemia of chronic disease) may be seen, and polymyositis can be associated with an elevated absolute lymphocyte count.
  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are positive in a significant proportion of patients but are nonspecific; they can serve as a starting point for the serologic work-up because many laboratories offer protocol-based reflex testing for autoantibody subsets (eg, myositis-specific autoantibodies).
  • Myositis-specific autoantibodies (eg, anti-Jo-1, anti-MDA5, anti-SRP) provide diagnostic and prognostic information.  In particular, anti-Jo-1 (anti–histidyl-tRNA synthetase) is associated with increased risk for ILD and is frequently positive in antisynthetase syndrome.
  • Myositis-associated antibodies include a number of autoimmune markers that can be seen in overlap myositis associated with various systemic autoimmune disorders.  Major antibodies include anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La/SSB, and antinuclear ribonucleoprotein (anti-RNP).

Imaging and special studies



  • Electromyography/nerve conduction studies:  Abnormal electrical activity in muscles (eg, fibrillation potentials) is nonspecific but can support the diagnosis and rule out motor neuron disease.
  • MRI:  MRI can reveal myoedema and regional hyperintensity, which correlate with muscle inflammation and guide muscle biopsy location.

Muscle biopsy



Muscle biopsy in IMM syndromes typically shows inflammatory infiltrates, muscle injury and necrosis, and repair processes within muscle fibers.  Distinct clinicopathologic correlates include the following:



  • Polymyositis:  focal, patchy endomysial inflammation (direct invasion of individual muscle fibers), with a predominance of CD8+ T cells and monocytes/macrophages and without prominent vascular involvement
  • Dermatomyositis:  mixed cellular infiltrate (predominantly CD4+ T cells, beta cells with occasional plasma cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells), microangiopathy, and perifascicular atrophy and fibrosis in a segmental pattern with vasculopathy
  • Inclusion body myositis:  endomysial inflammation, vacuolization of myocytes, and intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions
  • Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy:  pronounced necrotic changes with scant inflammatory infiltrate


Skin biopsy in dermatomyositis can show interface dermatitis (inflammation at the junction between the epidermis and dermis), vacuolization of basal keratinocytes, immune complex deposition, and mucinous changes.

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions can mimic dermatomyositis and polymyositis, and a thorough evaluation is crucial to ensuring accurate diagnosis.  Important differential diagnoses include the following:



  • Hypothyroid myopathy:  proximal muscle weakness is very common in untreated hypothyroidism but is usually associated with muscle pain and tenderness.
  • Drug-induced myopathy:  certain medications (eg, statins) can cause muscle weakness, but it is usually associated with pain.
  • Myasthenia gravis:  often causes painless proximal muscle weakness, but extraocular and/or bulbar weakness is usually present, and symptoms are intermittent rather than persistent and progressive.
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica:  can sometimes cause weakness in the proximal limb muscles, but pain is usually the predominant symptom; inflammatory markers are elevated but muscle enzymes (eg, CK) are typically normal.
  • Fibromyalgia:  is a very common disorder characterized by fatigue and muscle pain; subjective weakness may occur but objective motor strength and laboratory findings are normal.

Management



Management of the IMMs usually requires an extended course of treatment (years), with attention to mitigating the adverse effects of therapy.  A multidisciplinary program that includes medication and nonpharmacologic measures is typically needed.  Primary modalities include the following:



  • Corticosteroids:  Systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) are the mainstay of initial treatment to suppress inflammation and improve muscle strength.  High doses may be required.  However, with long-term use, corticosteroid myopathy can cause additional muscle weakness that may cloud assessment of the primary disorder.
  • Immunosuppressant (steroid-sparing) medications:  These medications, especially azathioprine, methotrexate, calcineurin inhibitors (eg, cyclosporine), and mycophenolate mofetil, are used alongside corticosteroids to dampen the immune response and reduce the dose-related toxicity of long-term corticosteroid use.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin:  can be helpful in some cases, particularly for rapidly progressive disease.
  • Skin management:  skin symptoms in dermatomyositis can be mitigated with aggressive sun protection, antihistamines (eg, hydroxyzine), amitriptyline, apremilast, and topical corticosteroids.
  • Other supportive measures:  Physical therapy for strength training, joint flexibility, balance, and gait aids can be helpful for many patients.  Speech therapy assessment may be needed for dysphagia and other oropharyngeal symptoms.  Medications for pain management and osteoporosis prevention may be necessary, depending on individual needs.

Complications



  • Interstitial lung disease:  Inflammation of the lung interstitium can manifest as shortness of breath and cough.  In severe instances, respiratory failure can occur.  The risk is increased in patients with anti-Jo-1 antibodies.
  • Dysphagia:  Involvement of oropharyngeal and esophageal muscles can lead to dysphagia with an increased risk for aspiration.
  • Cardiomyopathy:  Myocardial involvement can lead to myocarditis, congestive heart failure, arrhythmia, and heart block.  Patients also have an increased risk for coronary atherosclerosis.
  • Calcinosis (
    image 3
    ):  Yellowish-white papules are due to the deposition of calcium hydroxyapatite crystals in subcutaneous tissues, causing pain and limiting mobility, particularly in juvenile dermatomyositis.

Relation to malignancy



The risk for occult malignancy is increased in patients with IIMs, especially adult-onset dermatomyositis; the risk in juvenile dermatomyositis is not significantly increased.  Prominent associations include adenocarcinoma of the breast, lung, ovaries, colon, and prostate, as well as nasopharyngeal carcinoma, melanoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  The pathophysiology for this association is unclear but may be related to cross-reactive autoantigens (eg, in the muscles and on tumor cells).  Regular, age-appropriate cancer screening (eg, mammography, colonoscopy) is essential, and other studies (eg, chest x-ray, gynecologic evaluation) are often considered at initial diagnosis for further investigation of underlying malignancy.

Prognosis



The prognosis for dermatomyositis and polymyositis varies depending on the severity of the disease, response to treatment, and presence of complications.  Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment can lead to significant improvement and long-term disease control.  However, some individuals may experience persistent muscle weakness or relapses.  ILD is the most significant factor affecting prognosis, with a higher risk for mortality if it is severe.

Summary



The immune-mediated myopathies (IMMs) are a group of autoimmune conditions characterized by humoral and cell-mediated immunity against muscle fibers.  In addition to polymyositis and dermatomyositis, major IMM categories include inclusion body myositis, immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy, antisynthetase syndrome, and overlap myopathy (ie, myositis occurring in the context of another autoimmune connective tissue disorder).



  • Dermatomyositis presents with painless, symmetrical, proximal muscle weakness associated with characteristic skin lesions (eg, Gottron papules, heliotrope rash).
  • Polymyositis presents with similar proximal weakness but without skin lesions.


Muscle enzymes (eg, creatine kinase, aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase) and inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein) are elevated.  Antinuclear antibody test is usually positive, and confirmatory tests include myositis-specific antibodies (eg, anti-Jo-1).  Diagnosis also usually requires muscle biopsy unless pathognomonic skin lesions are present.



Treatment typically includes systemic corticosteroids and immune-suppressing (steroid-sparing) drugs; prolonged treatment and extensive supportive care may be needed.  In addition, IMMs (especially dermatomyositis) are associated with an increased risk for malignancy; age-appropriate screening tests should be updated.
